thread.title: 'What did Trump know?': US legislators seek probe into Flynn's resignation
thread.title_full: 'What did Trump know?': US legislators seek probe into Flynn's resignation

title: 'What did Trump know?': US legislators seek probe into Flynn's resignation
text:
Democratic Senator Chris Coons asked why Mr Flynn was allowed to remain in his post for so long after the White House was warned of the potential for blackmail. 
"This isn't just about what happened with General Flynn," Mr Coons told MSNBC. 
"What did President Trump know? What did the President know and when did he know it?" Mr Coons said, echoing a question made famous by the Watergate scandal, which forced president Richard Nixon to resign in 1974. External Link: @SenSanders: Michael Flynn leaving the administration isn't enough to clear up questions that many of us have about the Trump team's ties with Russia 
Two leading Republicans in the Senate — Bob Corker and John Cornyn — also said the intelligence committee should investigate Mr Flynn's contacts with Russia and that he may need to testify. 
Republican senator Roy Blunt, a member of the same committee, told a local radio station that the panel should interview Mr Flynn "very soon" as part of its investigation into attempts by Russia to influence the US election. 
"General Flynn's resignation also raises further questions about the Trump administration's intentions toward Vladimir Putin's Russia," said Senator John McCain, a leading Republican voice on foreign relations. 
But the highest-ranking Republican in Congress, House of Representatives Speaker Paul Ryan, sidestepped questions about whether legislators should look into Mr Flynn's Russia ties, adding he would leave it to the Trump administration to explain the circumstances behind Flynn's departure. 
Mr Flynn, an early and enthusiastic supporter of Mr Trump, was a strong advocate of a softer line toward Russian President Vladimir Putin , and his departure from the key post could hinder Mr Trump's efforts to warm up relations with Moscow. Trump worried about continued leaks from Washington Photo: Mr Flynn's conversations with the ambassador reportedly occurred when the Obama administration slapped sanctions on Russia. (Reuters: Carlos Barria) 
The Washington Post reported last week that the issue of sanctions came up in the conversations with the ambassador, although Mr Flynn told Mr Pence they had not. 
In his first public comment about the Flynn issue since the resignation, Mr Trump deflected the focus to leaks from his administration. External Link: @realDonaldTrump: The real story here is why are there so many illegal leaks coming out of Washington? Will these leaks be happening as I deal on N.Korea etc? 
In his resignation letter, Mr Flynn acknowledged he had "inadvertently briefed the Vice President-elect and others with incomplete information regarding my phone calls with the Russian ambassador." 
A US official familiar with the transcripts of the calls with Mr Kislyak said Mr Flynn indicated that if Russia did not retaliate in kind for Mr Obama's December 29 order expelling 35 Russian suspected spies and sanctioning of Russian spy agencies, that restraint could smooth the way toward a broader discussion of improving US-Russian relations once Mr Trump took power. Video: Law professor Khaled Beydoun discusses the implications of Mr Flynn's resignation. (The World) 
To the surprise of some observers at the time, Mr Putin did not take retaliatory measures — Mr Trump praised his restraint. 
Mr Flynn's discussions with the Russian diplomat could potentially have been in violation of a law known as the Logan Act, banning private citizens from negotiating with foreign governments about disputes or controversies with the United States. 
However, nobody has been prosecuted in modern times under the law, which dates from 1799. 
Vice Admiral Robert Harward, who served under Defence Secretary James Mattis, is the leading candidate to replace Mr Flynn, two US officials said. 
The scramble to replace Mr Flynn began on Monday evening and continued with phone calls and meetings into the early hours of Tuesday in an effort to enable Mr Trump to make a decision and put the matter behind him as soon as possible, said an official involved in the effort. 
Also under consideration was retired General David Petraeus, a former CIA director whose reputation was tainted by a scandal over mishandling classified information with his biographer, with whom he was having an affair. More on this story:
